title: Athletics FABS Membership
description:
This dataset visualizes the number of unique memberships registered within the Fitness and Athletics Booking (FABS) system, by academic year. For example, the academic year of 2021 spanned from September 1, 2021 to August 31, 2022.

FABS memberships allow access to and reservations of several Athletic facilities, such as: fitness center, women-only gym, faculty pool, 50m pool, 400m track, indoor track...

While FABS allows for 9 different account types, this dataset categorizes into 4 distinct demographic groups:
  • Undegraduate (student)
  • Graduate student and alumni
  • Staff affliation: faculty, staff, and family member
  • External: contract, external instructor, guest, and Tamkeen

charts.title: Number of Unique FABS Memberships
charts.subtitle: As the university continues to expand over the year, the number of registrations has exhibited a clear upward trend. However, there was a significant decrease of staff affiliated and guest memberships in AY20-21 during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic when remote working policies and campus access restrictions were in place. Undergraduate students saw only a minor 14% year-by-year decrease in 2020 as most students were allowed to stay on-campus, followed by an almost two-fold increase in AY21-22.

charts.title: Percentage of Demographic Groups in FABS
charts.subtitle: In relative terms, undergraduate students have remained the largest group of Fitness Facilitiy users in recent years, representing around two-third of all users.

title: Athletic Facilities Check-in
description: This dataset visualizes the number of check-ins throughout different Athletic facilities on campus, such as: fitness center, women-only gym, faculty pool, 50m pool, 400m track, indoor track... This dataset serves as a proxy on estimating the fitness level and physical activity of the community. Temporal data visualizations also allow us to avoid peak times in indoor spaces and spread our exercises more evenly throughout a day or a week.

charts.query: SELECT A, B, C, D, F, I, J
charts.title: Average Number of Facilities Check-in Throughout the Day
charts.subtitle: As the typical workday draws to an end at around 5-6pm for students, faculties, and staffs, this time window the busiest period for fitness activities. While the number of check-in varies throughout the day, with a relatively smaller peak in the morning from 8-9am, the figure doesn't usually surpass half of that of the busiest time. For those who prefer a quieter workout, aim for early-morning or midday timeslots where the occupancy rate is only a quarter of the busiest time.

charts.title: Facilities Check-in Per Week Day, Normalized to the Max Value of Each Year
charts.subtitle: While the level of fitness activities exhibits a strong diurnal variation, it remains more stable throughout the weekdays. The second day of the weekend and the first work day of the week have historically been off-peak days where attendance is around 10-30% less compared to the busiest day. Interestingly, even when the UAE changed its weekend days on January 1, 2022 (from Fri-Sat to Sat-Sun), this pattern still holds true: 2021's off-peak days are Sat and Sun, whereas 2022's off-peak days are Sun and Mon.

charts.title: Heat Map for the Average Hourly Number of Check-in, by Day of the Week
charts.subtitle: Explore them and see for yourself the differences between each year, each day of the week, and each hour.

charts.title: Heat Map for the Total Monthly Number of Check-in, by Day of the Week
charts.subtitle: Explore them and see for yourself the differences between each year, each day of the week, and each month.

charts.title: Total Monthly Facilities Check-in, Historical
charts.subtitle: Finally, this visualization shows how much fitness activity has increased since the introduction of FABS which can be attributed to the gradual relaxation of COVID-19 restrictions and the increase in on-campus residents over the period of 2020-2022.

title: Food Waste
description: This dataset visualizes food waste in the Dining Hall D2. The amount of food waste is measured by weighing the plate-waste (leftover food from the customers) with calibrated scales operated by the Dining service provider. Past data visualizations, such as the green calendar-styled monthly food waste counter at the entrance of D2, have brought about awareness among the community. Not being constrained by the crowded space in the Dining Halls, this online visualization allows for a more detailed and nuanced break-down of the dataset into timeline, monthly, by-meal statistics...

rawDataTables.query: SELECT A, B, C, D, E, F ORDER BY A DESC LIMIT 10

charts.title: Mean Daily Food Waste (kg) by Week
charts.subtitle: These charts visualize the mean daily food waste by week, in total or by each meal (breakfast, lunch, and dinner). The shaded interval representing 1 standard deviation (not applicable in the stacked chart). Hover on the line chart to see the week number. From this visualization of average daily food waste by month, it is evident that the absolute amount of food waste is on the rise (as COVID restrictions were loosened in 2022 and as the student population continues to increase year-by-year). When the data is broken down into the three constituent meals, the increase in 2022 can primarily be traced back to a significant rise of food waste from lunch and dinner.

hAxis.title: Month - Year (hover on chart to see week number)

charts.title: Historical Daily Food Waste (kg)
charts.subtitle: Interact with this calendar to explore the amount of daily food waste (desktop recommended). The unit of measurement is in kilogram(s) of food waste. On average, a plate full of food weighs around 0.5kg (150g for each portion of starch, protein, and vegetable), not including other side dishes. Thus, to imagine how many plates full of food can be saved for those in need, simply multiply the kilogram figure by 2.

charts.title: Percentage of Food Waste By Meal
charts.subtitle: Lunch and dinner make up the majority of campus' food waste, each accounts for roughly two-fifths of the total wastage for a given day.

charts.title: Food Waste (kg) per Day of the Week (With 1 Standard Deviation)
charts.subtitle: The level of food wastage is relatively similar between the different days of the week, with relatively small dips over the weekend. This might be a surprise to some because most faculties/staffs do not come to campus and students often go out to other dining outlets in the city during the weekend.

title: Air Quality
description:
CITIESair was originally a part of a student Capstone project (NYUADAir) in Spring 2021. It publicized, for the first time, air quality around the NYU Abu Dhabi campus to the community. Recognizing the potential of this project, and to further raise awareness and encourage sustainable behaviors within and beyond the university community, CITIES decided to scale it up by equipping the network with higher-grade sensors and transfering technology to other schools in Abu Dhabi.

The air quality network on NYU Abu Dhabi now consists of 3 stations: an outdoor station situated in between A1 and A2 building, an indoor station in the Campus Center, and another indoor station in the Dining Hall D2. In 2022, we also designed and featured real-time air quality banners on NYUAD's Student Portal and Intranet, while maintaining the existing physical air quality screens in the Campus Center and Dining Hall D2.

rawDataTables.query: SELECT A, B, C, D, G, H, I, L, M, N ORDER BY A DESC LIMIT 10

charts.title: Historical Snapshots of Air Quality Index

subcharts.query: SELECT A, K, L, M, N, O, P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, W, X, Y

charts.title: Daily Air Quality Index, All Time
Percentage of Daily Air Quality Categories by Month
Average PM2.5 Concentration (µg/m3) by Day of the Week, with 1 Standard Deviation
Hourly Average PM2.5 Concentration (µg/m3) by Month

subcharts.subtext:
• Outdoor dust concentration often peaks in the early morning, followed by a sharp drop until noon and a gradual build-up throughout the night. This is consistent with other studies in Abu Dhabi [1] [2], and is potentially explained by an high humidity levels causing secondary formation of aerosol particles and hygrosopic growth of aerosols.
  • For those with a sharp eye for anomalies, it is instantly clear that an influx of students every September causes a remarkable deterioration of the air quality during lunch when students usually hang out with friends. And as the semester progresses, more and more students opt for take-outs for convenience. During the past two Ramadans (May 2020 and Apr 2021), similar deteriorations are observed during dinner and Suhur (before sunrise) compared to other months.

• Inside the Campus Center, PM2.5 levels stay relatively constant throughout the day, with a small increase during the morning rush hours as a lot of staff and students enter the building
  • For those with a sharp eye for anomalies, it is instantly clear that an influx of students every September causes a remarkable deterioration of the air quality during lunch when students usually hang out with friends. And as the semester progresses, more and more students opt for take-outs for convenience. During the past two Ramadans (May 2020 and Apr 2021), similar deteriorations are observed during dinner and Suhur (before sunrise) compared to other months.

• In the Dining Hall, the concentration gradually builds up throughout the day, hitting bigger peaks after each meal (breakfast, lunch, and dinner) with small troughs in-between meals. This might be explained by cooking activities, especially grilling, that produce volatile microscopic particles, and to a lesser extent, people repeatedly entering and exiting the building.
  • For those with a sharp eye for anomalies, it is instantly clear that an influx of students every September causes a remarkable deterioration of the air quality during lunch when students usually hang out with friends. And as the semester progresses, more and more students opt for take-outs for convenience. During the past two Ramadans (May 2020 and Apr 2021), similar deteriorations are observed during dinner and Suhur (before sunrise) compared to other months.

charts.subtitle:
The above graph shows the hourly PM2.5 concentration (µg/m3) throughout a day, on average. Each thin line represents the hourly average concentration for a calendar month (hover on the line to see which month it is), while the highlighted line represents the all-time-averaged hourly concentration.
Here are some clear trends:
charts.reference:
[1] Al-Jallad, Fadi A., Clarence C. Rodrigues, and Hamda A. Al-Thani. "Ambient Levels of TSP, PM10, PM2. 5 and Particle Number Concentration in Al Samha, UAE." Journal of Environmental Protection 8.09 (2017): 1002.
[2] Phanikumar, Devulapalli Venkata, et al. "Assessment of particulate matter concentration and gaseous pollutants in urban and rural regions over the Emirate of Abu Dhabi, UAE." Journal of Atmospheric and Solar-Terrestrial Physics 199 (2020): 105217.

charts.title: Correlation Between Daily Average Outdoor and Indoor PM2.5 Concentrations (µg/m3)
charts.subtitle: Indoor air quality is shown to moderately correlate with outdoor air quality, with R2 around 0.5-0.6 (hover on the best fit equations to see the exact R2 value). Predictably, thanks to the air filtration systems, indoor PM2.5 concentrations are significantly lower than its outdoor counterpart, around 6x and 4x lower for Campus Center and Dining Hall D2, respectively. Due to cooking activities, air quality in the Dining Hall is estimated to be 1.5x worse than the Campus Center when comparing their daily average.

charts.title: [External Data] Annual PM2.5 Concentration (µg/m3) by Country
charts.subtitle: Source data: IQAir - World's Most Polluted Countries
